summary: This is a letter from attorney Brad Edwards to an Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. Edwards addresses the U.S. Attorney's Office's change in position, proposes stipulating to additional uncontested facts about a non-prosecution agreement, and requests documents including the full agreement and victim interview reports.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Author of the letter; attorney for Jane Doe #1 and other victims; requests documents and stipulations regarding the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the case; pleaded guilty in Florida State Court on June 30, 2008, and is covered by a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: One of the victims; represented by attorney Brad Edwards; received a victim notification on July 9, 2008.

connections.description: Edwards is the attorney representing Jane Doe #1, as indicated in the victim notification reference.
Edwards, as victims' attorney, is advocating against the non-prosecution agreement that benefits Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered guilty pleas in Florida State Court, was sentenced, and imprisoned in Palm Beach County.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Negotiated
events.description: A non-prosecution agreement was negotiated between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein, later amended twice in 2007.

events.title: Victim Notification Sent
events.description: AUSA sent a victim notification to Jane Doe #1 via her attorney, Bradley Edwards, explaining the terms of the non-prosecution agreement.

keyFacts: A non-prosecution agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida was negotiated in September 2007, amended twice, and prevented federal charges for sex crimes against the victims.

The victims and their attorneys were not informed about the non-prosecution agreement until after June 30, 2008, due to a confidentiality provision complied with by the U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI.
The U.S. Attorney's Office had changed its position and was not attempting to work out undisputed facts, focusing instead on the lack of filed federal charges and Epstein's state guilty plea.
Attorney Brad Edwards requested the full non-prosecution agreement, FBI interview reports of his clients, and assistance in securing a transcript of the victims' petition hearing.
